subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis. The epigynum of
Argiope carvalhoi
resembles that of
A. florida Chamberlin & Ivie, 1944
and
A. blanda
O. Pickard-Cambridge, 1898
in the shape of the median septum and the rim ( Levi 1968: fig. 100 ) and in the large septal lip ( Levi 1968: fig. 143 ) respectively. It can be distinguished from these species and the remaining species of the genus, except from the Australasian
A. probata Rainbow, 1916
and
A. protensa L. Koch 1872
, by the long and narrow abdomen, without lateral lobes ( Fig. 20B ).
Argiope carvalhoi
can be distinguished from
A. protensa
by the shape of the epigynum, which is very elongated and have the copulatory openings facing dorsally in the latter species ( Levi 1983: figs 98–101 ). The epigynum of
A. carvalhoi
also differs from that of
A. probata
( Levi 1983: figs 107–108 ) in the larger septal lip ( Fig. 21A ) and narrower median plate in posterior view ( Fig. 21B ).

paragraph.materialsCitation: Female. Holotype from Barra do Tapirapés , Santa Terezinha , Mato Grosso , Brazil ( MNRJ 1538 ). Carapace pale yellow in the cephalic region and light brown in the thoracic region ( Fig. 20A ). Chelicerae pale yellow with numerous short, proximal-median macrosetae. Endites and labium pale yellow. Sternum pale yellow with three lateral depressions that coincide with brown markings. There are small tubercles between each depression, the anterior larger than the others, and an unpaired tubercle in the posterior portion. Palp pale yellow with numerous spiniform macrosetae. Legs with a pale-yellow background covered by numerous dark brown spots, more densely distributed on the first femur. All coxae pale yellow, the first with small ventral macrosetae. First trochanter with numerous short, prolateral macrosetae. Opisthosoma with two anteriorly directed humps, and a pair of dorsal lines extending from the anterior humps to the posterior apex, and a smaller band extending from the middle to posterior apex ( Fig. 20A ). Venter light brown, with a pair of white bands extending from the epigastric groove to the spinnerets ( Fig. 20B ). Total length 9.00; carapace 2.50 long, 2.20 wide in the thoracic area, 1.20 wide after the posterior median eyes. Femur I length 4.20, patella 1.20, tibia 3.30, metatarsus 4.20, tarsus 1.40 (right leg). Patella II 1.00, III 0.70, IV 1.10. Tibia II 3.10, III 1.50, IV 2.70. Epigynum in ventral view with a procurved rim connected to a straight and slender median septum, making an Y-shaped structure ( Fig. 21A ). Septal lips well developed and projects laterally ( Figs 21A–B, E ). Copulatory openings visible laterally ( Fig. 21E ). Posterior margin of septum rounded in lateral view ( Fig. 21C–D ). In posterior view, median septum connected to rim and septal lip emerging from copulatory openings ( Fig. 21B, E ).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks. The holotype of
Mecynogea carvalhoi
was not available at the time H.W. Levi was preparing his revision on
Mecynogea ( Levi 1997 )
. Thus, based on the original description of the species ( Mello-Leitão 1944 ), he proposed it as a tentative synonym of
Manogea porracea
, a nomenclatural act not accepted subsequently ( World Spider Catalog 2017 ).

subSubSection.paragraph:
The holotype has a male embolus attached to each copulatory opening ( Fig. 21 A, B, D, F ), indicating that the male embolus can serve as a mating plug, as observed in other species of the genus (
Uhl et al. 2010
and references therein). These detached emboli are the only parts of the male known at the moment, and both show a long pendant, a fork-like apophysis present in the embolus of several species of the genus ( Jäger 2012 ).
Distribution. Known only from the type locality, in northern Brazil ( Fig. 16 )
